text: Department of the Treasury Internal Revenue Service
IRM 13.3.1.1(3). Deleted reference and information related to obsolete phone system.
IRM

Terms and Deﬁnitions, deﬁnes a Case Advocate (CA) as a Taxpayer Advocate Service (TAS) employee with the following titles: Associate Advocate, Bilingual Associate Advocate, Bilingual Lead Case Advocate, Bilingual Senior Associate Advocate, Lead Case Advocate, and Senior Associate Advocate.

IRM 13.3.1.1.5 Terms and Deﬁnitions, deﬁnes a Case Advocate (CA) as a Taxpayer Advocate Service (TAS) employee with the following titles: Associate Advocate, Bilingual Associate Advocate, Bilingual Lead Case Advocate, Bilingual Senior Associate Advocate, Lead Case Advocate, and Senior Associate Advocate.

IRM 13.3.1.2 Initial Research. Deleted obsolete procedural direction and renamed Steps to Take for Speciﬁc Situations, IRM 13.3.1.3. Updated procedures in this section from the previous IRM 13.3.1.2.1 section of the IRM.
IRM 13.3.1.2(1), Overview-Receiving Calls on the NTA Toll-Free Intake Line. Added information directing any IRS employee who is directed to IRM 13.3 to follow the guidance.

IRM 13.3.1.2(4), Overview-Receiving Calls on the NTA Toll-Free Intake Line. Provides the NTA assistor with a greeting when the call is connected and directs them to follow guidance in IRM 21.1.1.4 (1)(2)(3)(4), Communications Skills afterwards.

IPU 13U1693 issued 12-03-2013 IRM 13.3.1.2.(1) where new paragraph (4) was added instructing assistors to provide taxpayers with phone numbers for the assigned case advocate, manager, LTA and the Area Director under speciﬁc circumstances. All remaining paragraphs renumbered accordingly. Guidance now located in IRM 13.3.1.3(3)(b) but removes the requirement for providing the Area Director’s phone number.

IPU 13U1693 issued 12-03-2013 IRM 13.3.1.2.(1) which added new paragraph (11) to reference the, ″Memorandum of Understanding Between Wage and Investment Division, Customer Account Services and the National Taxpayer Advocate Concerning the Direct Transfer of Telephone Calls from NTA Toll-Free Assistors to Taxpayer Advocate Service Intake Advocates Under a Proof of Concept”, signed on November 18, 2013 was not incorporated because the guidance is obsolete.

IRM 13.3.1.2(4). Added information related to NTA assistor’s initial contact with the caller.

IPU 12U1949 issued 12-14-2012 IRM 13.3.1.2(7) Updated Centralized Authorization File (CAF) fax phone numbers in Memphis and Ogden for use with Domestic Taxpayers. This is redundant because it exists in IRM 21.1.3.3, Third Party Authentication (POA/TIA/F706) so it was removed from IRM 13.3.

IRM 13.3.1.2(9), Overview-Receiving Calls on the NTA Toll-Free Intake Line. Added link to the Servicewide Electronic Research Program (SERP) Telephone Guide. Additionally, language was added directing NTA assistors to IRM 21.1.3.2.5, Authentication Transfer Procedures/Transfer

IRM 13.3.1.3, New TAS Cases. Renamed this section title to Steps to Take for Speciﬁc Situations and deleted previous guidance in this section. New TAS Cases guidance is found in IRM section 13.3.1.4 which was rewritten to align with new processes associated with indirect access NTA assistors now have through AMS to Taxpayer Advocate Management Information System (TAMIS).
IPU 13U1559 issued 10-24-2013 IRM 13.3.1.3(2) updating NTA phone number. now found in IRM 13.3.1.3(12), Steps to Take for Speciﬁc Situations.

IRM 13.3.1.3(1), Steps to Take in Speciﬁc Situation, added 5 business day timeframe for NTA assistors to provided to taxpayers when NTA assistors when NTA assistors generate an e-911 because TAS CCI locations are closed.
IRM 13.3.1.3(4)(a), Steps to Take in Speciﬁc Situations, case criteria 5-9 changed from 7 calendar days to 5 business days.

IRM 13.3.1.3(4)(a)Note. Added note explaining that during the initial case intake and assignment process, NTA assistors should only provide the taxpayer with the CA contact information. The note also provides information related to TAS initial case intake and assignment process.
IRM 13.3.1.3(4)(b). NTA assistor will provide the general local phone number of the Local Taxpayer Advocate (LTA) when the case has not been assigned to a CA during the initial case intake process.
13.3.1.4(6), New TAS Cases, provides guidance for handling taxpayers’ inquiries when occur while on hold for more than 90 minutes for a TAS IA.

IRM 13.3.1.4(9), New TAS Cases, provides extension numbers for transferring calls to the TAS line. If the call is related to a Potential New case or to a Closed TAS case, the call is transferred to extension 1788(English) or 1789(Spanish). However, if the call is related to an Open TAS case, the taxpayer will be transferred to extension 1791 (English) or 1792 (Spanish).
IRM 13.3.1.5 LTA Responsibilities for Cases Initiated by NTA Assistors was removed because procedures were obsolete.

IRM 13.3.1.5 Changed title from LTA Responsibilities for Cases Initiated by NTA Assistors. Section rewritten to align with new processes. All calls associated with a closed TAS case will be to TAS IAs during a speciﬁc timeframe while TAS locations are open. Also provided direction and information on TAS intake line hours of operations which provides less hours of service than Accounts Management (AM).
IRM 13.3.1.5, Closed TAS Cases guidance was added.
IRM 13.3.1.6 Changed title from Unavailability of TAMIS or Integrated Data Retrieval System (IDRS), to Unavailability of AMS and/or IDRS.
IRM 13.3.1-1 Exhibit − Removed fax sheet exhibit because it is designed to be completed online through the web link.
IRM 13.3.1, dated March 2, 2012 is superseded.
Primarily the National Taxpayer Advocate toll-free phone assistors. Secondarily, Taxpayer Advocate and all Operating Divisions and functions.
Bonnie Fuentes, Executive Director Case Advocacy, Intake and Technical Support
Table of Contents
Toll-free Procedures
) Purpose: This IRM section provides procedures for NTA assistors (Account Management (AM employees) responsible for answering incoming calls on Scope and NTA’s Toll-Free Intake Line (
). This IRM section is also to IRS employees who are directed by management to follow IRM
or when IRM
is referenced by other IRS IRMs. (

) Audience: These procedures primarily apply to IRS employees preforming duties associated with answering incoming calls from taxpayers seeking assistance. Secondary audiences would include TAS employees, and employees of Operating Divisions and Functions. (
) Policy Owner: The Executive Director Case Advocacy, Intake and Support (EDCA-ITS), who reports to the Deputy National Taxpayer (DNTA). (
) Program Owner: The EDCA-ITS who reports to the DNTA. (

) The IRM provides comprehensive guidance and processes to IRS who answer incoming calls from taxpayers seeking TAS assistance. The guidance also provides direction for handling inquiries that do not meet criteria or for taxpayers who already have a case in TAS. (
) IRM

was revised to incorporate: • Procedures from the Memorandum of Understanding between Wage and Investment Division, Customer Account Services and NTA ing the Direct Transfer of Telephone Calls from NTA Toll-Free to Taxpayer Advocate Service Intake Advocates Under a Proof of Concept signed on November
) Pursuant to IRC
(c), the Office of the Taxpayer Advocate (known as Taxpayer Advocate Service (TAS)) shall assist taxpayers to resolve with the IRS. (
) The EDCA-ITS, is the executive responsible for providing policy and to NTA assistors (AM employees) who answer incoming calls on the NTA Free Intake Line. (
) AM employees assigned to NTA toll-free telephone applications should the procedures contained in this IRM as well as other resources. (
) IRS employees who are directed by management or other IRMs should the procedures contained in this IRM as well as other resources. (
) Reports for key telephone matrixes associated with the service provided NTA Toll-Free Intake Line are derived from phone data captured by the Management Operations Center. (
) The following table contains a list of terms used throughout this IRM:
V (
) Internal Revenue Manual
Policy Owner: The Executive Director Case Advocacy, Intake and Technical Support (EDCA-ITS), who reports to the Deputy National Taxpayer Advocate
AM employees assigned to NTA toll-free telephone applications should follow the procedures contained in this IRM as well as other resources.
IRS employees who are directed by management or other IRMs should the procedures contained in this IRM as well as other resources.
The following table contains a list of terms used throughout this IRM:
2 13.3 National Taxpayer Advocate (NTA) Toll-Free Program
A TAS employee trained to conduct in
depth inter

views with taxpayers to conﬁrm TAS criteria, take cases into TAS, provide updates on TAS cases, and other actions per IRM guidance. Taxpayers who are transferred by NTA assistors to TAS intake applications will speak to a TAS IA. Also referred to as an Intake Specialist in TAMIS position titles.
A set of standards or conditions established by TAS to determine if a taxpayer’s inquiry will become a TAS case, see IRM
, TAS Case Criteria.
) For a comprehensive listing of any IRS acronyms, please refer to the Database. (

) NTA assistors will use a variety of tools, in conjunction with this IRM when answering the NTA Toll-Free Intake Line. Below are some of the most common: a. TAS Zip Code Routing and Toll-Free Resources Shar
oint; b. Publication
, Taxes Beneﬁt Everyone; c. Servicewide Electronic Research Program (SERP); d. The Source for Telephone Numbers;
NTA assistors will use a variety of tools, in conjunction with this IRM when answering the NTA Toll-Free Intake Line. Below are some of the most
) In addition to the tools listed above, other relevant IRMs NTA assistors will but not limited to when answering incoming calls received on the NTA Intake Line are: a. IRM
, Disclosure of Official information; b. IRM
, TAS Case Criteria; c. IRM
, Customer Account Services d. IRM
, IMF Identity Protection Specialized Unit (IPSU) Paper; e. IRM
, Potentially Dangerous Taxpayers; and f. IRM
, Frivolous Return Program. (

) TAS Centralized Case Intake (CCI) operation was established to enable taxpayers seeking TAS assistance to speak directly with a TAS CCI intake advocate (IA). Account Management (AM) employees assigned to the NTA plication or other IRS employees who are directed to IRM
will follow guidance in the procedures based on the speciﬁcs of the taxpayer’s inquiry. (

) The following are guiding principles for the NTA Toll-Free Intake Line: a. All employees are encouraged to assist taxpayers resolve inquiries normal procedures can fully resolve the inquiry or complaint. This be a primary goal of all employees. A referral to TAS is NOT needed if the NTA assistor can resolve the issue. b. Any taxpayer indication or inference of hardship should be taken at value and construed to meet TAS criteria. Refer to IRM
, Taxpayer Advocate Case Criteria and IRM

, Same Day tion by Operations. c. NTA assistors should refrain from giving taxpayers a false sense of dence that TAS has the authority to immediately ﬁx or provide relief for problems. Instead, NTA assistors should take a conservative approach when a taxpayer’s inquiry meets TAS criteria. The NTA assistor should inform the taxpayer that they will have an opportunity to speak with a TAS IA for further evaluation. Additionally, TAS is committed to taxpayers and will review their case for opportunities for relief within conﬁnes of the law. (
) NTA assistors assigned to answer calls received on the NTA Toll-Free Intake telephone number (
) may receive calls from: a. Taxpayers who have contacted the NTA Toll-Free Intake Line
In addition to the tools listed above, other relevant IRMs NTA assistors will use but not limited to when answering incoming calls received on the NTA Toll-Free Intake Line are:
IRM
, Disclosure of Official information; IRM
, TAS Case Criteria; IRM
, Customer Account Services IRM
, IMF Identity Protection Specialized Unit (IPSU) Paper; IRM
, Potentially Dangerous Taxpayers; and IRM
, Frivolous Return Program.
(12-10-2020) Overview-Receiving Calls on the NTA Toll-Free Intake Line

) The following are guiding principles for the NTA Toll-Free Intake Line: a. All employees are encouraged to assist taxpayers resolve inquiries normal procedures can fully resolve the inquiry or complaint. This be a primary goal of all employees. A referral to TAS is NOT needed if the NTA assistor can resolve the issue. b. Any taxpayer indication or inference of hardship should be taken at value and construed to meet TAS criteria. Refer to IRM
, Taxpayer Advocate Case Criteria and IRM

, Same Day tion by Operations. c. NTA assistors should refrain from giving taxpayers a false sense of dence that TAS has the authority to immediately ﬁx or provide relief problems. Instead, NTA assistors should take a conservative approach when a taxpayer’s inquiry meets TAS criteria. The NTA assistor should inform the taxpayer that they will have an opportunity to speak with a TAS IA for further evaluation. Additionally, TAS is committed to taxpayers and will review their case for opportunities for relief within conﬁnes of the law. (
) NTA assistors assigned to answer calls received on the NTA Toll-Free telephone number (

) may receive calls from: a. Taxpayers who have contacted the NTA Toll-Free Intake Line about the same issue, b. Taxpayers who identify their problems as meeting TAS criteria and are routed to the NTA application via touch tone responses from their phones, and c. Taxpayers who have a rotary dial telephone and default through the phone script. (
) The NTA assistor should state the following when connected to the caller, “National Taxpayer Advocate intake line” and then follow the guidance in
), Communications Skills. (
) NTA assistors will follow disclosure procedures in IRM
, Required Taxpayer Authentication.

All employees are encouraged to assist taxpayers resolve inquiries normal procedures can fully resolve the inquiry or complaint. This be a primary goal of all employees. A referral to TAS is NOT needed if the NTA assistor can resolve the issue. Any taxpayer indication or inference of hardship should be taken at face value and construed to meet TAS criteria. Refer to IRM
, Taxpayer Advocate Case Criteria and IRM

, Same Day Resolu- tion by Operations. NTA assistors should refrain from giving taxpayers a false sense of dence that TAS has the authority to immediately ﬁx or provide relief for problems. Instead, NTA assistors should take a conservative approach when a taxpayer’s inquiry meets TAS criteria. The NTA assistor should inform the taxpayer that they will have an opportunity to speak with a TAS IA for further evaluation. Additionally, TAS is committed to assisting taxpayers and will review their case for opportunities for relief within the conﬁnes of the law.
NTA assistors assigned to answer calls received on the NTA Toll-Free Intake telephone number (1- 877-777-4778) may receive calls from:
a. Taxpayers who have contacted the NTA Toll

Free Intake Line about the same issue, b. Taxpayers who identify their problems as meeting TAS criteria and routed to the NTA application via touch tone responses from their phones, and c. Taxpayers who have a rotary dial telephone and default through the phone script.
4 13.3 National Taxpayer Advocate (NTA) Toll-Free Program
National Taxpayer Advocate (NTA) Toll-Free (
) When responding to a third party (anyone other than the taxpayer), NTA assistors should follow guidance found in IRM
, Third Party tion (POA/TIA/F
) NTA assistors should probe and research the taxpayer’s inquiry to determine they can resolve the issue per IRM
, Same Day Resolution by Opera- tions. If this is not possible, they should determine if TAS criteria is met by utilizing systems such as IDRS and AMS, see IRM
, TAS Case Criteria. NTA assistors should also be familiar with IRM
, Exceptions to Taxpayer Advocate Service Criteria. (
) If the taxpayer’s inquiry meets TAS criteria, take the appropriate actions in IRM
, New TAS Cases. (

) If the taxpayer’s problem does not meet TAS criteria (e.g., taxpayer is ing the IRS for the ﬁrst time about a refund or dialed the incorrect IRS in the notice or letter), the NTA assistor will transfer the call to the correct telephone application/extension (NTA assistors can use the Servicewide Elec- tronic Research Program (SERP) Telephone Transfer Guide as a resource for making this determination, SERP Alerts, or information found in the letter or notice). When appropriate, the NTA assistor will also follow IRM
, thentication Transfer Procedures/Transfer PIN for inquiries associated with taxpayer’s account. (

) If the taxpayer needs more information about TAS after being informed that their issue does not meet TAS criteria: a. Explain the purpose of TAS. TAS is an independent organization within the IRS that helps taxpayers resolve tax problems which have not been resolved through normal channels. TAS is not a substitute for IRS procedures or the formal Appeals process. TAS cannot reverse or technical tax determinations. b. Transfer the call to the appropriate telephone application. (
) If a taxpayer speciﬁcally insists on TAS assistance, continue to work with the taxpayer as if the case meets TAS criteria. Follow the procedures in IRM
), New TAS Cases. Criteria code ″

″ (indicating system or procedure failure) will be applicable and should be added in the Accounts agement Services’ (AMS) notes along with information stating the ″taxpayer speciﬁcally requested TAS assistance.″ Note: When entering a TAMIS history through AMS, NTA assistors should only include factual information. Editorial or personal comments should not be input. (

p.m. EST (

For open TAS cases after-hours, NTA assistors will add a note using the Account Management Services (AMS) Taxpayer Advocate Management Infor- mation System (TAMIS) Case Information Window (CIW) requesting that the case advocate (CA) contact the taxpayer. Provide the taxpayer with the name of the CA and their phone number. In both instances, inform the taxpayer they will be contacted within
business days.
) For inquiries related to TAS closed cases, follow IRM
, Closed TAS cases. (

) If there is an open TAS case involving the same issues(s) and there is any dication of one of the following Special Circumstances: • Immediate economic harm to the taxpayer; • The taxpayer indicates they have not been able to contact their CA; • The taxpayer expresses dissatisfaction with how their case is being handled in TAS; or • The taxpayer speciﬁcally requests to speak to a TAS employee. a. Use the AMS TAMIS CIW to conﬁrm the taxpayer has the correct telephone number for their CA. b. If the taxpayer or representative has the correct telephone number, provide them with the CA’s manager and LTA’s information. Provide name, job title, and telephone numbers of the employees. This tion can be found in the TAS Directory or in the Discovery Directory. IRM
, Communications Skills and IRM
, Photo ID Cards. c. Transfer the call to CCI, per the guidance in IRM
), TAS Cases. (

) If there is an open TAS case and no Special Circumstance was identiﬁed after the discussion with the taxpayer, take the following actions: a. If the taxpayer has not waited the required amount of time for contact business days for case criteria
; or
business days for case

), ask the taxpayer to be patient and provide the taxpayer the information found in the AMS TAMIS CIW, if available. Note: During the initial case intake and assignment process, the AMS TAMIS CIW will also display the names of employees who are CAs but their names appear along the way in the AMS TAMIS prior to ﬁnal case assignment. Their contact information should be provided to the taxpayer. Some of these Employee Titles Intake Specialist, Associate Advocate Manager, Secretary, LTA other titles. Only provide taxpayers the name of the TAS CA (i.e., Associate Advocate, Bilingual Associate Advocate, Lead CA, Bilingual Senior Associate Advocate, Lead CA, or Associate Advocate). b. If a CA has not been assigned, inform the taxpayer that their case is important to TAS but their case has not been assigned to the speciﬁc who will work their issue(s). Provide the taxpayer with the general number for the LTA and ask the taxpayer to be patient. c. Enter a new history item in the ″New History″ ﬁeld of the AMS TAMIS
If there is an open TAS case involving the same issues(s) and there is any in- dication of one of the following Special Circumstances:
If there is an open TAS case and no Special Circumstance was identiﬁed after the discussion with the taxpayer, take the following actions:

TAMIS CIW will also display the names of employees who are not CAs but their names appear along the way in the AMS TAMIS prior to ﬁnal case assignment. Their contact information should be provided to the taxpayer. Some of these Employee Titles are: Intake Specialist, Associate Advocate Manager, Secretary, LTA or other titles. Only provide taxpayers the name of the TAS CA (i.e., Associate Advocate, Bilingual Associate Advocate, Bilingual Lead CA, Bilingual Senior Associate Advocate, Lead CA, or Senior Associate Advocate).

b. If a CA has not been assigned, inform the taxpayer that their case is important to TAS but their case has not been assigned to the speciﬁc who will work their issue(s). Provide the taxpayer with the general office number for the LTA and ask the taxpayer to be patient. c. Enter a new history item in the ″New History″ ﬁeld of the AMS TAMIS CIW and save. This information will be saved in AMS and TAMIS histories. d. If the taxpayer has been contacted by the CA but no longer has the contact information, provide the taxpayer with the information from the AMS TAMIS CIW and enter a history item.
6 13.3 National Taxpayer Advocate (NTA) Toll-Free Program
a. Inform the taxpayer that you will complete a NTA fax sheet, (located on the TAS Zip Code Routing and Toll-Free Resources Shar

oint page check the “Taxpayer Request Immediate CA Contact” block), and send the CA’s manager. b. Apologize to the taxpayer and ask if they would like to be transferred again to the TAS intake application. If so, transfer the call per IRM
), New TAS Cases. c. Provide the taxpayer with the name and phone number of the CA. d. Inform the taxpayer that they should be contacted within
business days. e. Send the completed fax sheet immediately to the CA’s manager and add a history item to the case. (
) If the taxpayer has never contacted TAS before and the problem meets TAS criteria, follow the directions in IRM
, New TAS Cases. (

) If the taxpayer was informed previously by a NTA assistor that their problem was resolved during their phone conversation, but research shows it wasn’t resolved: a. Try to resolve the issue, per IRM
), New TAS Cases. b. Transfer the call to CCI if you cannot resolve the issue, per the in IRM
), New TAS Cases. (
) If the taxpayer requests TAS assistance, but the problem does not meet TAS criteria, follow the guidance in IRM
), Overview-Receiving Calls on the NTA Toll-Free Intake Line. (
) If the taxpayer insists on TAS assistance, even though TAS criteria is not met, continue to work with them and refer the inquiry to TAS per IRM
), Overview-Receiving Calls on the NTA Toll-Free Intake Line. (
) If there are any freeze codes on an account, do not take any action without complete IDRS research per IRM
, Researching Freeze Codes. (
) If it is determined during research on IDRS or AMS that there is an open gressional inquiry, transfer the call to appropriate TAS application, per the guidance in IRM
)New TAS Cases. (
) If the taxpayer insists on speaking with the NTA, explain to them that they are provide taxpayers with the direct phone numbers to the National Taxpayer
a. Inform the taxpayer that you will complete a NTA fax sheet, (located the TAS Zip Code Routing and Toll-Free Resources Shar

oint check the “Taxpayer Request Immediate CA Contact” block), and the CA’s manager. b. Apologize to the taxpayer and ask if they would like to be again to the TAS intake application. If so, transfer the call per IRM
), New TAS Cases. c. Provide the taxpayer with the name and phone number of the CA. d. Inform the taxpayer that they should be contacted within
business days. e. Send the completed fax sheet immediately to the CA’s manager and a history item to the case.
If the taxpayer was informed previously by a NTA assistor that their problem was resolved during their phone conversation, but research shows it wasn’t
If there are any freeze codes on an account, do not take any action without complete IDRS research per IRM 21.5.6.3 , Researching Freeze Codes.
provide taxpayers with the direct phone numbers to the National Taxpayer Advocate or the Deputy, National Taxpayer Advocate.
) Probe and research the taxpayer’s inquiry to determine if you should refer the issue to TAS. See IRM
, TAS Case Criteria, for guidance. NTA assistors should also be familiar with IRM
, Exceptions to Taxpayer Advocate Service Criteria because TAS will generally not accept inquiries that fall within Systemic Burden Criteria
for issues related to Processing of Original Return, Unpostable/Rejected Returns, Processing of Amended Returns and Injured Spouse Claims.
page (
) If the taxpayer’s issue meets TAS criteria or the taxpayer speciﬁcally TAS assistance and you can resolve it the same day, follow IRM
, Same Day Resolution by Operations. (
) If you can’t resolve the taxpayer’s issue and it meets TAS criteria, proceed to IRM

), New TAS Cases. Note: Do not provide the taxpayer with the IRS general response guidelines in IRMs because they may be different now with TAS involvement. The CA will provide the taxpayer with timeframes related to the case. (
) If the NTA assistor determines the issue is associated with a business try to determine if the taxpayer’s issue(s) meets TAS criteria. If so, proceed IRM

), New TAS Cases. The NTA assistor should notate in AMS history if they were not trained or if they do not have access to Business Master Files (BMF) account information. If it is not clear to the NTA assistor that the business inquiry meets TAS criteria, the NTA assistor should also transfer to the appropriate TAS application with a complete AMS history summary and include the appropriate notations stated above their training and access. (

) If a taxpayer indicates they called previously regarding a new case and their call was transferred to TAS but never spoke to a TAS employee due to a system or personal disconnect and no case was found after searching in the AMS TAMIS CIW: a. Check the AMS history for ″General Account Inquiry″ for ″Toll-free Line Initiative (TFILI)″ or ″CCI″ and related comments. b. If veriﬁed, advise the taxpayer you will transfer them again and advise the taxpayer to call
if the call is disconnected prior to speaking to a TAS IA. c. Transfer the call to the appropriate phone extension,
for (English)
for (Spanish). d. If there is no information in the AMS history, probe the taxpayer to determine if the issue should be referred to TAS per guidance in IRM
, New TAS Cases. (
) If a taxpayer with a new case request communicates that they waited on for more than
minutes after being transferred to the TAS intake but was disconnected prior to speaking with a TAS IA, the NTA assistor will generate an e-
through AMS for the taxpayer if their inquiry meets TAS criteria: a. NTA assistor will advise the taxpayer to be patient and expect TAS contact in
business days for case criteria
, and
business days case criteria
b. Document AMS history summarizing communications and actions ated with the contact. c. If the taxpayer calls back after the
or

business day wait period because TAS has not contacted them, the NTA assistor will provide an update to the taxpayer based on information found in AMS and the TAMIS CIW. For example, it there is a TAS case established, the NTA assistor can inform the taxpayer that TAS accepted their e-

and es- tablished a case. Ask the taxpayer to be patient and provide the CA information or general office number to the LTA office if no CA has been assigned. Always leave TAMIS and AMS histories. Internal Revenue Manual #
If the NTA assistor determines the issue is associated with a business account, try to determine if the taxpayer’s issue(s) meets TAS criteria. If so, proceed to IRM

), New TAS Cases. The NTA assistor should notate in the AMS history if they were not trained or if they do not have access to Business Master Files (BMF) account information. If it is not clear to the NTA assistor that the business inquiry meets TAS criteria, the NTA assistor should also transfer to the appropriate TAS application with a complete AMS history summary and include the appropriate notations stated above regarding their training and access.

13.3 National Taxpayer Advocate (NTA) Toll-Free Program

) When referring the taxpayer to TAS, enter the following information in AMS: a. The literal ″CCI″ under the issue ″General Account Inquiry″; b. Best telephone number for TAS to make contact (indicate whether cell or business); c. Best time to call the taxpayer/Power of Attorney (POA) between
a.m. and

p.m. local time; d. Name of the persons to contact (Mr./Ms./POA, etc.); e. Tax year(s) involved; f. Clear and complete explanation of the issue(s) and problem(s); g. If a business case, the NTA assistor should provide the following note AMS ″Not trained in BMF”; h. If the case is closed, enter ″TAS closed case″ and the case ﬁle of the closed case in AMS history; i. Applicable TAS criteria code; and, j. days since taxpayer sent correspondence, etc.). (

) TAS will notify W&I NTA managers when TAMIS is down. NTA assistors should: a. Research AMS history to determine if a TAS case exists; b. If there is an open TAS case, follow guidance in IRM

oint page, and check the ″Potential Reopen″ block. Send the completed sheet via fax the same day to the TAS office of the CA’s manager who closed the case.
